title: Ukiyo-e: Hell Courtesan
transcript:
Narrator: What follows is a conversation between curator Janice Katz and writer and editor at Teen
Vogue, Lucy Diavolo.

Janice Katz: She is--

Lucy Diavolo: Wooow. So metal.
<laughter>

Janice Katz: This is “The Hell Courtesan.”

Lucy Diavolo: Wow. I’m in love. <laughs>

Janice Katz: She was actually Buddhist and she would spar with the monk that you see there dancing on
the skeleton’s head, about different questions of Buddhist doctrine, and she’s always shown with these
really elaborate robes that show all these different scenes in hell. In this case there’s a slight twist as to
what’s going on on her robe, because instead of these really scary and off-putting images of hell, you get
these really auspicious images of hell. What I mean by that is instead of the red flamelike patterns that
you see are made by red coral, which is actually seen as a good luck symbol. But it’s still very, very
ghoulish, right? You know, but there she stands at this traditional image of your idealized beauty, but all
around her you have something, this surreal, ghoulish scene.

Lucy Diavolo: Just the look on her face to be so unbothered by the fact that she’s literally dragging hell
behind her is very much aspirational--
<laughter>

Lucy Diavolo: --I would say. This is such a fascinating piece to me because of all of this imagery and
this sort of hellacious, I guess, symbolism that’s happening here.

Janice Katz: Yeah. I think the artist is definitely using her to portray a subversive figure, somebody who
is a courtesan, somebody who is outside the norms of society, and yet she’s the one who can embrace
these Buddhist ideas, understand hell.

Lucy Diavolo: You know, embracing demonization I think is such a powerful tool for people who find
themselves on the margins of society, in finding a way to say, “People aren’t going to treat me well. I
know that, but it’s going to be because of what they think of me and the notions that they’re going to
preconceive of me, so let me play with that, let me live in that space,” and instead of trying to be an angel
every day for the rest of my life to prove them wrong, show them that the devil isn’t really that bad. Hell
isn’t really something to be dreaded, it’s a place where everything’s possible.
